body: isn't this easily achieved already with doing tuning over the `sp` parameter?

Yes, but there may be some other heuristics which are less computationally expensive, e.g. using information from the time index or seasonality tests.

In terms of API design, that may be an interesting case for an estimator that passes on a hyper-parameter in a pipeline.

so what's "done" for this issue then? Identify one or two methods that can infer seasonality parameter, and implement them as forecaster?

Also, do we need another scitype "parameter estimator"?
Yes, I think that would be an interesting case to see if we can come up with a good `ParameterEstimator` design. So far it's more of a discussion topic.

One tool for detecting seasonality is via auto-correlations. I read about it in the [AutoTheta paper](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/338507620_Generalizing_the_Theta_method_for_automatic_forecasting). See first ~8 lines of Page 5 of the paper for brief description and references for further details.

Roughly: calculate autocorrelations and if an autocorrelation is particularly big (see paper for exact formula to determine the cutoff) then we say there is seasonality.

Yes, in the M4 study they used a similar heuristic based on a hypothesis test, there's some code for it [here](https://github.com/mloning/sktime-m4/blob/2b51b9c41968c2065b26e655df70a41c0a414e3a/scripts/utils.py#L314).

issue.title: Auto Detect Seasonal Period for annual data

labels.name: time_series
labels.description: Topics related to the time series

repository.name: pycaret
repository.description: An open-source, low-code machine learning library in Python

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Auto Detect `seasonal_period` for annual data. Currently it assumes 1 by default so it has to be specified manually in setup.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Figure out a way to compute the `seasonal_period` from this data instead of asking user to input it.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Manual entry of `seasonal_period` can not be automated since it varies from dataset to dataset.

**Additional context**
Feedback received from `sktime` dev days presentation

body: Another option is to use fast-fourier transformation. I believe that's what Hyndman's packages use.

There is also an implementation:
```python
from seasonal.seasonal import fit_seasons
```
https://github.com/welch/seasonal
Nice! The periodogram there is the fft method I was referring to.

design-wise and implementation-wise, this is now resolved by `BaseParamFitter` - at least as an experimental prototype.

Regarding the `seasonal` package, I will open a new issue, which will allow us to develop the `BaseParamFitter` interface further.

rename.to: [ENH] principled interface to infer seasonal periodicity from data

issue.title: [ENH] interface the `seasonal` package as a parameter estimator for seasonality (`BaseParamFitter` descendant)

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
We now have an interface design for generic parameter estimators, with `BaseParamFitter`.
(original design issue: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/1056)

Still experimental, we should further explore it by interfacing useful parameter estimators.

@mloning suggested the methods in the `seasonal` package in https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/1056, given the existing base class interface and seasonality examples it seems like a good first issue.
